findings.title: Potential sandwich attack
findings.description: An attacker can manipulate the exchange rate by front-running a transaction to purchase assets and make profits by back-running a transaction to sell assets.

findings.title: Access Control and Authorization
findings.description: Centralization privileges of Solaris Finance can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of critical contract functions.
findings.function: setInitialAddresses(), setFeeAddresses(), setMaxTxAmount(), setbuyFee(), setsellFee(), excludeAddressFromFee()

findings.title: Assets Manipulation
findings.description: Potential sandwich attack happens when an attacker observes a transaction swapping tokens or adding liquidity without setting restrictions on slippage or minimum output amount.

findings.title: Ownership Control
findings.description: Centralization privileges of Solaris Finance can lead to centralization-related losses.
findings.function: setInitialAddresses(), setFeeAddresses(), setMaxTxAmount(), setbuyFee(), setsellFee(), excludeAddressFromFee()

findings.title: Liquidity Access
findings.description: Smart contract function addLiquidity() sends liquidity to owner() without setting restrictions on slippage or minimum output amount, making it vulnerable to potential sandwich attacks.

findings.title: Stop and Pause Trading
findings.description: The functions addLiquidity() and swapTokensForEth() do not have restrictions on slippage or minimum output amount, making them vulnerable to potential sandwich attacks.

findings.title: Ownable Library Verification
findings.description: The Ownable library has been implemented with public functions owner, renounceOwnership, and transferOwnership, which can lead to potential security risks if not handled properly.
